reviewText: My husband loves all of the Lone Ranger titles, so when Dreamwork Classics offered me the opportunity to try these out and comment on them for a review, I was happy to do so.The works are amazingly clear given the age of the original series, and the sound quality was well done. I found no problems with watching them, except to get them away from my husband long enough to check them out for a review.This particular DVD offers 8 episodes of the original television series and is a wonderful way to reintroduce yourself (or your children) to this wonderful masked man. Black and white - about 200 minutes (or a nice rainy afternoon) to watch.As it says on the cover "Kemo Sabe - Trusted Friend." And I was always told it meant "One who knows." After checking online, I discovered that the most likely translation is "Trusted Scout."Five stars for the quality of the reproduction.
Title: Lone Ranger - Kemo Sabe

reviewText: The lone Ranger rides again. Eight episodes from the golden age of T.V. Clayton Moore, and Jay Silverheels. Were the stars. TOM
Title: Lone Ranger - Kemo Sabe

reviewText: The Lone Ranger was a very popular television series that aired from 1949-1957. I was born in 1946, and after my parents bought our first TV set in 1949, The Lone Ranger soon became one of our favorite shows. I can still remember the opening bars of the William Tell Overture, the Merita Bread commercials, and the Lone Ranger's iconic "Hi-yo, Silver, away!" The Lone Ranger was the first western series produced specifically for television. Dozens more westerns followed over the next few decades, but The Lone Ranger was the pioneer, debuting at a time when only a few states even had a TV broadcasting station.The DVD has eight episodes:* Trouble for Tonto - episode #45 (1950)* The Fugitive - episode #131 (1954)* Enfield Rifle - episode #149 (1955)* The Tell-Tale Bullet - episode #162 (1955)* Framed for Murder - episode #177 (1955)* Courage of Tonto - episode #201 (1957)* Mission for Tonto - episode #216 (1957)* The Banker's Son - episode #218 (1957)The last three episodes (from the series' final season) are in color; the earlier shows are black and white. The aspect ratio is 4:3, which was the format of the TV sets made in that era. The episodes have an average runtime of 22-23 minutes each. The DVD includes a nice sampling of the Lone Ranger series, from #45 (the first season) to #218 (the final season). The episodes on this DVD feature Tonto, although he's in every episode, I believe.I was mesmerized watching these old shows that I first watched on TV more than a half-century ago. No, the acting isn't that great, and the production values weren't even close to those of today's TV shows, but it's a fascinating look into the past at one of the earliest successful TV series. The Lone Ranger was the ABC Network's first hit series and helped to establish the network as one of the big three in TV.The DVD is a treasure trove for Lone Ranger fans, and well worth a look for anyone interested in the development of television shows, especially westerns.A review copy of the DVD was provided by the seller.
Title: Lone Ranger - Kemo Sabe

reviewText: Very good DVD.  Very reasonable Price.  A great variety of episodes to see the Lone Ranger.  I would recommend this DVD.
summary: Lone Ranger Kemo Sabe Trusted Friend
Title: Lone Ranger - Kemo Sabe

reviewText: I'm old enough to remember watching Lone Ranger episodes when they originally aired as I camped out in front of our black and white console TV. When not watching Lone Ranger, I might have been watching Howdy Doody, Mickey Mouse,  Ding Dong School, Superman, or Paul Winchell and Jerry Mahoney. This DVD is nostalgic for some and a chance to witness television history for others. With commercials omitted the episodes run 22-23 minutes; for old times' sake I would have liked to view a few "brief and important messages" from General Mills.Having had the opportunity to sample a number of Lone Ranger DVD's, I would recommend this "Kemo Sabe" DVD as one's first purchase. It's a good sampling of stories showing the repeated themes of loyalty, good vs. evil, trust, redemption, and racial harmony.  In many of the episodes over the life of the series, a young man makes a foolish mistake and is invariably steered straight by the wise Lone Ranger.All of the episodes move quickly and much story is compacted in those 20-some minutes. With its roots in radio, the shows make use of a narrator to move the story along, and the Lone Ranger's ability to make perceptive observations and draw quick conclusions also help with the story flow.The viewer get to sample a few color versions of the show, an interesting contrast in viewing experience. I actually found the black and white episodes to be crisper and sharper, the color being a bit muted in the non black and white shows.Bottom Line - This DVD represents some wonderful television history.  Lone Ranger can be campy at times, and the camera effects can't compare with today's (pause the action during fist fights for fun) but you'll never tire of that uplifting theme song and the heroic qualities of an iconic character from the bygone days of television.
Title: Lone Ranger - Kemo Sabe

reviewText: A very pleasant surprise to see Tonto become the main character in all but one of the episodes on the DVD. I have been a great fan of the Lone Ranger since the early 50's, but it was super to see Tonto up front in these 7 of 8 shows.
Title: Lone Ranger - Kemo Sabe
